title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 18, 2019).

Saudi Arabia will soon restore most of its oil output and return to normal production levels in weeks, the country's energy ministry said. Crude prices posted declines on Tuesday.

For the first time in over a decade, the Fed injected cash into money markets to pull down interest rates after technical factors led to a sudden cash shortfall.

Banking agencies moved to ease a postcrisis rule that could free up nearly $40 billion for big global banks.

Entertainment heavyweights have spent over $2 billion on classic TV shows in recent weeks as they aim to win streaming customers.

AT&T's CEO defended his strategy and likely successor in his first public remarks since a challenge by activist hedge fund Elliott.

General Motors' use of temporary workers has emerged as a key bargaining issue as the UAW negotiates a new labor contract.

FedEx sharply cut its profit forecast for the year, sending the firm's shares plunging 10% after hours.

U.S. stocks ticked up as oil prices retreated and investors looked ahead to an expected Fed rate cut. The S&P 500 gained 0.3%.

AB InBev is taking a second shot at launching an IPO in Hong Kong for its Asian business.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 18, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
